docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 24 TAKING EVIDENCE OTHERWISE THAN AT TRIAL [rr 24.1–24.20]

heading.title: PART 24 TAKING EVIDENCE OTHERWISE THAN AT TRIAL [rr 24.1–24.20]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 24 TAKING EVIDENCE OTHERWISE THAN AT TRIAL [rr 24.1–24.20]

leg:heading.title: TAKING EVIDENCE OTHERWISE THAN AT TRIAL [rr 24.1–24.20]

entry.emph: Orders for pre-trial examination of witnesses — Rules 24.3, 24.5 and 24.10

row.entry: These provisions permit orders for taking the evidence of witnesses by a court appointed examiner. They also permit an order for the issue of a letter of request to other judicial bodies.

entry.emph: Conduct of pre trial examinations — Rules 24.6–24.11

row.entry: These provisions regulate the procedures for conducting such an examination, including appointing the examination date and venue, taking evidence otherwise than on oath, examination of additional persons, and dealing with objections to evidence.

entry.emph: Recording and reporting of examinations — Rules 24.12–24.15

row.entry: These provisions regulate the recording of the examination evidence and the manner in which the examination record is to be provided to the court..

entry.emph: Default, expenses and perpetuation of testimony — Rules 24.16–24.20

row.entry: These rules deal with expenses associated with examinations and letters of request. They permit the court to enforce compliance by witnesses. They also permit proceedings for perpetuation of testimony.
This Part only applies to proceedings in the Supreme and District Courts: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part is based on the former SCR Part 27, DCR Part 25. There is no significant change in the substance of the rules.
Alternative procedures for taking evidence at trial — video link ‥ [24.3.20]
Credibility isues — examination of witnesses and alternative procedures ‥ [24.3.25]
Default of witness, order to attend after ‥ [r 24.16]
Discretion to order examination — “interests of justice” ‥ [24.3.10]
Discretion to order examination — pragmatic guidelines ‥ [24.3.15]
Discretion to order examination — witness’ unavailability ‥ [24.3.5]
Documents — orders for production at examination ‥ [24.3.30]
Evidence, manner of giving and recording ‥ [r 24.6] , [r 24.12] , [r 24.13]
Examination of a person outside Australia — letters of request ‥ [24.3.40]
Examiner — persons who may be appointed — foreign examination venue ‥ [24.4.10]
Examiner — persons who may be appointed — generally ‥ [24.4.5]
Foreign examination venue — power to order examination ‥ [24.3.35]
Judge or court officer as examiner ‥ [r 24.4]
The Hague Convention and related legislation ‥ [24.5.10]
The power to compel a witness' attendance ‥ [24.8.5]
Witnesses whose evidence may be taken ‥ [24.3.45]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.1] r 24.1 Application of Part

leg:heading.title: Application of Part

p.text: This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court or the District Court.
Legislation cited in [24.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995.
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992.

The rules complement the statutory provisions enacted to facilitate implementation of the Hague Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters. The statutory provisions are contained in the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 and the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth). In addition, the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) contains provisions authorising the service of subpoenas in Australia requiring attendance in, or production to, the courts of any state jurisdiction. Although this latter power removes one of the possible justifications for the use of the present rules, because it renders interstate witnesses compellable, it does not prevent orders being made under them: Rickard v Sutherland (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 153; Bolton v Kienzle (1926) 43 WN (NSW) 30.
Legislation cited in [24.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.6(2)(a), r 31.6(2)(b), r 31.6(3).
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 8(2)(b).
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994 s 15(2), s 9(2)(b).

The essential purpose of the procedures contemplated by the relevant legislation, and the present rules, is to allow the evidence to be tendered at the trial. However, the evidence must satisfy the same criteria of admissibility as if it was given at the trial: see r 31.6(2)(b) ; Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 8(2)(b) ; Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) s 9(2)(b) . In addition, evidence is not admissible if the court is satisfied the witness is within the state and able to attend the hearing: r 31.6(2)(a) of the UCPR. (However, in Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd (No 37) [2001] NSWSC 838; BC200106410 it was held that neither r 31.6, nor the statutory provisions, precluded the admissibility of examination evidence taken within the state pursuant to a specific direction made in proceedings in the court). Even if examination evidence is technically admissible, the court has a discretion to exclude the evidence whenever it considers that it is in the interests of justice to do so: r 31.6(3) ; Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) s 15(2) . The provisions of ss 135 and 136 of the Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) and (NSW) may also provide a basis for excluding the evidence.
Legislation cited in [24.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Pt 52, UCPR r 52.2.

The rules in this Part are principally concerned with evidence being taken for the purpose of proceedings in the court. Proceedings to take evidence for the purpose of foreign proceedings are brought by an application under UCPR Pt 52 . However, many of the provisions of this Part also apply to examinations conducted for the purpose of foreign proceedings (see UCPR r 52.2 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.2] r 24.2 Construction of certain references (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Construction of certain references (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1)

p.text: In this Part, a reference to the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 , or to a provision of that Act, includes a reference to the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth, or to the corresponding provision of that Act.
Legislation cited in [24.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994 s 10, s 7, s 8.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 20, 21, 23, ss 6, ss 7, ss 9.

The power to make orders in relation to superior court proceedings is contained in s 7 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) and ss 6 and 20 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. The Foreign Evidence Act applies to state courts when they are exercising federal jurisdiction: see s 3 of the Act. The Evidence on Commission Act applies to state courts when they are not exercising federal jurisdiction: see s 18 of the Act. The power in relation to inferior court proceedings is contained in s 10 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) and ss 9 and 23 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. Under the Foreign Evidence Act a court of the state (which would include the District Court) when exercising federal jurisdiction is an inferior court: s 6. Under the Evidence on Commission Act an inferior court means a court of the State (other than a superior court) except when exercising federal jurisdiction: s 18. The power to make incidental procedural directions is provided for in s 8 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) and ss 7 and 21 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995.
Legislation cited in [24.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994 s 7(1)(b).
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 6(1)(b).

It is common to refer to evidence taken otherwise than at trial as evidence taken on commission. This expression derives from a former practice, and statutory provisions, under which a superior court issued a formal commission for the taking of evidence: Callen v Partridge [1962] NSWR 1052; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 211 . References to evidence being taken on commission survive in legislative provisions such as s 7(1)(b) of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) and s 6(1)(b) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. Nevertheless, there is no provision in the rules for the procedure that would apply to such a commission, and the procedure is regarded as practically obsolete, having been superseded (in relation to the taking of foreign evidence) by letters of request and the statutory provisions: see Elna Australia Pty Ltd v International Computers (Aust) Pty Ltd (1987) 14 FCR 461 at 466; 74 ALR 232 per Gummow J and [24.3.30] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.3] r 24.3 Order for examination of witness (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1A; DCR Part 25, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Order for examination of witness (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1A; DCR Part 25, rule 1)

p.text: For the purposes of any proceedings, the court may make an order for the examination of a person, otherwise than at trial, at any place:
in New South Wales, or
outside New South Wales, but in Australia, or
outside Australia.
An order under this rule:
must nominate the person by whom the examination is to be conducted (the examiner), and
may specify the time at which, or within which, the examination is to be conducted.

level.toc-caption: [24.3.5] Discretion to order examination — witness’ unavailability

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 20, ss 6, s 6(2).
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994 s 7.

heading.title: Discretion to order examination — witness’ unavailability

p.text: There is no express limitation on the exercise of the power to order evidence being taken “otherwise than at the trial”. The permissive statutory criterion is simply curial satisfaction that the order is “in the interests of justice”: see ss 6 and 20 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 and s 7 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth). The potential width of the discretion is inevitably narrowed, however, by the restrictions on the admissibility of such evidence: as to which see [24.1.10] . Those restrictions mean that the power typically falls to be exercised in two situations: (i) where the prospective witness is within the jurisdiction but will (or may, because of age or infirmity: Bidder v Bridges (1884) 26 Ch D 1 ) be unable to attend the hearing of the proceedings; and (ii) where the witness is outside the jurisdiction and cannot be compelled to attend the hearing: see also s 6(2) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. Within those two situations, further relevant considerations include the materiality of the proposed evidence to the proper determination of the proceedings, likely cost, difficulty and delay in obtaining the evidence.

level.toc-caption: [24.3.10] Discretion to order examination — “interests of justice”

heading.title: Discretion to order examination — “interests of justice”

p.text: The ultimate criterion is whether it is in the “interests of justice” for the order to be made in the particular circumstances. The application of such a criterion involves some tension between two propositions. The first is that parties should not be shut out, by mere matters of relative convenience, from the ability to adduce all material evidence. The second is that it is generally desirable for all the witnesses to give evidence at the trial at the same time. Reasons for such a preference include the difficulty, and undesirability, of determining issues of credibility without seeing the witnesses, the possible inter-relationship of material evidence and the risk that the significance of particular matters may only become fully apparent at the hearing: Walt Disney Productions v H John Edwards Publishing Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 281 ; Berdan v Greenwood (1880) 20 Ch D 764; McKay Shoe Machinery Co Ltd v Turner (1900) 16 WN (NSW) 192; Bangkok Bank Ltd v Swatow Lace Co Ltd [1963] NSWR 488 .

level.toc-caption: [24.3.15] Discretion to order examination — pragmatic guidelines

heading.title: Discretion to order examination — pragmatic guidelines

p.text: In resolving that tension, in particular instances, the courts have from time to time formulated various general propositions that are intended to serve as guides. Some of these include the following:

an order should not generally be made in the absence of evidence of reasonable attempts to obtain the relevant evidence in other ways — either by encouraging the witness to attend, by using an alternative witness within the jurisdiction, by administering interrogatories, or by the production of documents: Armour v Walker (1883) 25 Ch D 673; Lawson v Vacuum Brake Co (1884) 27 Ch D 137 ; Lewis v Kingsbury (1888) 4 TLR 637 at 639; or by changing the trial venue: see r 8.2;

an order should not be made unless the likely materiality of the evidence is demonstrated, rather than merely asserted. The nature of the evidence should be described and sufficient additional matters disclosed to allow the court to satisfy itself that the order is desirable: Ehrman v Ehrman [1896] 2 Ch 611; Smith v Smith [1975] 1 NSWLR 725; (1975) 5 ALR 444;

subject to the preceding requirements, a bona fide application (Re Boyse (1882) 20 Ch D 760 ) in relation to a material witness of substance who is out of the jurisdiction (Ehrman v Ehrman , above) and which would not cause unreasonable delay if it was acceded to (Langen v Tate (1883) 24 Ch D 522 ) should usually be granted: Williams v Mutual Life Assn (1904) 4 SR (NSW) 677 at 680; Willis v Trequair (1906) 3 CLR 912; [1906] 12 ALR 507; Hardie Rubber Co Pty Ltd v General Tire & Rubber Co (1973) 129 CLR 521; 47 ALJR 462 .

level.toc-caption: [24.3.20] Alternative procedures for taking evidence at trial — video link

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.3.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.3.

heading.title: Alternative procedures for taking evidence at trial — video link

p.text: It will be observed, however, that many of the authorities deal with the exercise of the discretion where modern travel and communication facilities, including video tape, audio visual conferencing and telephone conferencing facilities, were not readily available. Their availability can significantly alter the way in which evidence is given at hearings and can also reduce the disadvantages of having evidence taken in advance of the hearing — even when significant credibility issues are likely to exist: Garcin v Amerindo Investment Advisors Ltd [1991] 4 All ER 655; [1991] 1 WLR 1140 (video link facilities); Director of Public Prosecutions v Alexander (1994) 33 NSWLR 482; 120 ALR 673; see further r 31.3 and notes thereto. Accordingly, an application for an order under the present rule should address the practical considerations relevant to the taking of evidence on commission and the desirability of doing so in preference to the use of video link facilities. Useful guidance on the contents of such an application is contained in Poschung v Jones (NSWSC, Levine J, 25 October 1996, unreported, BC9606849).

level.toc-caption: [24.3.25] Credibility isues — examination of witnesses and alternative procedures

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.3.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.13, r 31.3.

heading.title: Credibility isues — examination of witnesses and alternative procedures

p.text: Where the credibility of a particular witness will be a significant question, it is highly desirable that the court has a proper opportunity to observe the witness giving evidence. This consideration has led to some reluctance to order the non trial examination of witnesses where credibility is likely to be an important consideration: Berdan v Greenwood (1880) 20 Ch D 764 at 766, 768; Lawson v Vacuum Brake Co (1884) 27 Ch D 137 at 142 ; Burnside v Melbourne Edwards Publishing Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 281 at 282 ; Bangkok Bank Ltd v Swatow Lace Co Ltd [1963] NSWR 488 at 490 . However, if the evidence is able to be recorded so as to afford the court a proper opportunity to observe the witness and form a realistic assessment of demeanour, then the fact that credibility is likely to be a significant issue does not preclude the making of an order for examination of a witness: Director of Public Prosecutions v Alexander (1994) 33 NSWLR 482; 120 ALR 673. See also r 24.13 (audio-visual recording of evidence). Alternatively, consideration may be given to taking the evidence at the trial by using video link facilities: see r 31.3 and notes thereto.

level.toc-caption: [24.3.30] Documents — orders for production at examination

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.3.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992.

heading.title: Documents — orders for production at examination

p.text: A person within the jurisdiction is amenable to an ordinary subpoena requiring the production of documents. A person within Australia is amenable to a subpoena under the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth). A party to proceedings in the court may be required to attempt to obtain material documents that are in a foreign jurisdiction: Gambro Pty Ltd v Fresenius Medical Care Australia Pty Ltd (2002) 124 FCR 491; 194 ALR 65 . But where an order is made for the examination of a witness in a foreign jurisdiction there is a restricted ability to require the production of documents — because the production of documents does not constitute the “examination” of a witness, either for the purpose of the rule or its related statutory provisions: see Elna Australia Pty Ltd v International Computers (Aust) Pty Ltd (1987) 14 FCR 461 at 466; 74 ALR 232 ; and [24.5.20]

level.toc-caption: [24.3.35] Foreign examination venue — power to order examination

heading.title: Foreign examination venue — power to order examination

p.text: The statutory provisions referred to in r 24.2 expressly confer power to make orders for the examination of a person outside the state. Despite the territorial limitations on jurisdiction, a similar power to make orders for the examination of persons outside the jurisdiction had been exercised in Chancery in relation to both proceedings in the exclusive Chancery jurisdiction and the auxiliary jurisdiction in aid of actions at law: Moodaly v Morton (1785) 1 Bro CC 469; 28 ER 1245; Lord Belmore v Anderson (1792) 2 Cox Eq Cas 288; 30 ER 34; Hume-Williams and Macklin, Evidence of Commission, 2nd ed, Ch 1. The power to make orders of this kind was seen as part of the inherent, or in the case of statutory courts part of the incidental, powers of superior courts: Hardie Rubber Co Pty Ltd v General Tire & Rubber Co (1973) 129 CLR 521; 47 ALJR 462 ; Pearce v Button (1986) 8 FCR 408; 65 ALR 83; cf Parsons v Martin (1984) 4 FCR 235 at 240.

level.toc-caption: [24.3.40] Examination of a person outside Australia — letters of request

heading.title: Examination of a person outside Australia — letters of request

p.text: Historically the proposed examination on commission of a witness who was outside the jurisdiction could present at least two problems apart from the practical difficulty of assessing credibility issues relating to the evidence. These were: (i) the inability to compel a reluctant witness to attend the examination; and (ii) the existence of any legislation in the foreign jurisdiction that regulated the taking of evidence on oath, frequently by restricting the power to administer oaths to persons authorised under the laws of the foreign jurisdiction. As a means of overcoming these problems, a practice developed of issuing letters of request to the courts of the foreign jurisdiction. Although such a request obviously imposed no obligation on the foreign courts, considerations of comity led to acceptance of the procedure. The practical effect of the issuing of letters of request (letters rogatory) to the foreign court was equivalent to appointing it a commissioner for the taking of evidence, with the significant difference that the foreign court would use its own powers to administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses: Director of Public Prosecutions v Alexander (1994) 33 NSWLR 482 at 486; 120 ALR 673. This made the use of letters of request particularly effective and the practice grew to such an extent that in England, by the turn of the century, the letter of request procedure had almost entirely superseded the taking of evidence on commission outside the jurisdiction.

level.toc-caption: [24.3.45] Witnesses whose evidence may be taken

heading.title: Witnesses whose evidence may be taken

p.text: The two fundamental propositions which enliven the discretion are: (i) the probability of obtaining material testimonial evidence, and (ii) the probable unavailability of the witness to attend the hearing in the court. The first proposition may be satisfied by identifying a class, or group, of prospective witnesses, even though no particular individual can be shown to be a material witness. The second proposition may be established by inferences from the person’s domicile and employment: Hardie Rubber Co Pty Ltd v General Tire & Rubber Co (1973) 129 CLR 521 at 599; 47 ALJR 462 . Within these fundamental propositions, different considerations arise depending on the nature of the proposed witness and the apparent materiality of their evidence. For example, orders to take expert evidence will not be made against unwilling experts: see Re Application of Forsyth; Cordova v Phillips Roxanne Laboratories Inc [1984] 2 NSWLR 327 at 333 ; Seyfang v GD Searle & Co [1973] QB 148 . Conversely, any witness of fact may be the subject of an order, irrespective of whether the witness’ willingness to testify requires the compulsion of a subpoena. Even a party’s own evidence may be taken on commission: Nadin v Bassett (1883) 25 Ch D 21 ; Georgini v Electric Power Transmission Pty Ltd [1963] NSWR 258; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 41 . But views have been expressed to the effect that different considerations apply according to whether it is the plaintiff or the defendant who applies for the order. A plaintiff who applies to have their evidence taken on commission has been said to carry a heavy onus: Coch v Allcock & Co (1888) 21 QBD 178 ; Willis v Trequair (1906) 3 CLR 912 at 924; [1906] 12 ALR 507 ; Tomer v Crowle (1936) 53 WN (NSW) 78 ; Walt Disney Productions v H John Edwards Publishing Co Pty Ltd (1952) 69 WN (NSW) 281 . The proffered justification for such an approach is that a plaintiff who has chosen the jurisdiction should ordinarily be required to abide the consequences of that choice: Coch v Allcock & Co, above; Emanuel v Soltykoff (1892) 8 TLR 331. On the other hand, a defendant resident abroad is said ordinarily to be entitled to have their own evidence taken where they live: Emanuel v Soltykoff , above; Ross v Woodford [1894] 1 Ch 38 ; Willis v Trequair, above; Lees v Smith (1918) 35 WN (NSW) 53; Tomer v Crowle, above. This is particularly so where the named defendant is really only a nominal defendant — for example where the defence of the proceedings is in the control of an insurer: Callen v Partridge [1962] NSWR 1052; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 211 . These general propositions may be useful in so far as they highlight the different considerations that may arise in particular situations. However, they cannot be translated into guidelines that control the exercise of the discretion, particularly having regard to many alternatives that now exist as to the way in which evidence may be recorded and presented at the trial. In each case the ultimate question must be whether making the order is “in the interests of justice” in the particular circumstances.
Legislation cited in [24.3.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.14(4), (5), (6), r 24.3, r 47.5.

This rule applies to an arbitration under the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 in the same way as it applies to proceedings in court: UCPR r 47.5 . If an order is made under UCPR r 24.3 the other provisions of Pt 24 will apply except for UCPR r 24.14(4) , (5) and (6) ; UCPR r 47.5 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.4] r 24.4 Judicial officer or court officer as examiner (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1C; DCR Part 25, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Judicial officer or court officer as examiner (cf SCR Part 27, rule 1C; DCR Part 25, rule 3)

p.text: A judicial officer or other officer of the court may not act as an examiner otherwise than with the concurrence of the senior judicial officer.

An applicant for an order for a person’s examination, outside New South Wales, by a judicial officer or other officer of the court may request the proposed examiner to certify the amount which in his or her opinion should be paid into court as provision for expenses of the examination.

Such an order may be expressed to be conditional on the payment into court, by such person and within such time as the court may specify, of not less than the amount certified in accordance with subrule (2).
If satisfied that the amount paid or payable into court is or may be insufficient to provide for the expenses of the examination, the court, on application of the registrar:
may make an order directing the party on whose application the order for examination was made to pay into court such further amount, and within such time, as the court may specify, and
may make an order:
staying the proceedings, so far as they concern the whole or any part of any claim for relief by that party, or
suspending the operation of the order for examination,
until such payment is made.
The registrar must apply so much of the amount paid into court as may from time to time be required for the purpose in the payment, to or at the direction of the examiner, of:
expenses incurred in relation to the examination, or
advances for expenses to be incurred in relation to the examination.
Any amount paid under subrule (5) that is not required for expenses in relation to the examination must be repaid into court.

After the conclusion of the examination, on the examiner certifying that no expenses in relation to the examination remain unpaid or unrecouped from the money in court, the registrar must, subject to any order of the court, refund to the person by whom the money was paid into court (and, if more than one, in the same proportions as their respective payments into court) any money remaining in court.

level.toc-caption: [24.4.5] Examiner — persons who may be appointed — generally

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 83.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.9.

heading.title: Examiner — persons who may be appointed — generally

p.text: Any person may be appointed an examiner and may administer any oath required for the taking of the evidence: Supreme Court Act 1970 s 83 . The choice of the appropriate person in any particular case will depend upon a number of considerations including the convenience of the witness and the parties, the nature of the evidence, its materiality to the proceedings and the nature of any controversy that may exist in relation to it. The appointment of a practising lawyer as the examiner will usually have the twin advantages of combining flexibility as to the time and place of the examination, with knowledge of the appropriate procedures required to be followed: see r 24.9 . (Knowledge of the procedural requirements is especially important where the examination is being conducted for the purpose of foreign proceedings — because of the statutory restrictions on the scope of the examination: see [24.9.5] and [SCR 58.2.1]). Where issues of credibility arise, or where the evidence is particularly material to the resolution of the proceedings, it may be appropriate to appoint a judge as the examiner: see r 24.4.

level.toc-caption: [24.4.10] Examiner — persons who may be appointed — foreign examination venue

heading.title: Examiner — persons who may be appointed — foreign examination venue

p.text: The examinations conducted in another jurisdiction must comply with the laws of that jurisdiction. Those laws may require the examination to be conducted before consular officers, may limit the persons who may be examined and may not provide any powers to compel attendance or production of documents. Subject to any such limitation, the choice of examiner is a matter for the appointing court and depends upon the materiality of the evidence and the issues involved. It has been common for the examination to be carried out either by a forum lawyer or official. But a lawyer or other responsible person in the examination jurisdiction can also be appointed as the examiner.
Legislation cited in [24.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.11.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 39.

The limited role permitted to an examiner by the provisions of r 24.11 will usually mean that it is inappropriate for a judge to be made an examiner: Henderson v Primmer (1986) 68 ACTR 9; 84 FLR 265 citing Practice Note (Chancery: Deposition) [1981] 1 WLR 1560 at 1561 . However, this rule recognises that there may be occasions where the circumstances require that a judge be appointed. The rule makes any such possible appointment subject to the prior concurrence of the Chief Justice who, in accordance with s 39 of the Supreme Court Act 1970, has a principal role in the intra curial arrangement of the business of the court. The procedure to be followed when making such an application is for a notice of motion and affidavit to be filed in the usual way. (Applications in the Supreme Court should comply with Practice Note SC Gen 9 .) The application will then be referred to the Chief Judge of the relevant division of the court and the Chief Judge will consult with the Chief Justice. A form of order that was made on one such appointment, albeit one made before the introduction of the present rule, is set out in Universal Seaways Pty Ltd v Derby & Co (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers J, CL 12078/78, 17 April 1980, unreported). The order made in that case would now require some amendment to comply with the present rule.

Despite the requirement in r 24.4(2) it has been said that it is desirable for the amount of the contemplated expenses to be determined by a judicial officer other than the judge who is to be the examiner: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 49 ACSR 578; [2004] NSWSC 467; BC200403134 at [80] ; and, for the judge to formally certify the determination actually made by that other judge: see Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 50 ACSR 357; [2004] NSWSC 750; BC200405390 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.5] r 24.5 Letter of request (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2; DCR Part 25, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Letter of request (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2; DCR Part 25, rule 5)

p.text: After an order is made under section 6(1)(c) or 20(1)(c) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 for the issue of a letter of request, or an order of the same kind is made under section 9 or 23 of that Act, the party obtaining the order:
must lodge with the principal registrar:
a form of the appropriate letter of request, and
the interrogatories (if any) and cross-interrogatories (if any) to accompany the letter of request, and

if the letter of request is to be issued to the judicial authorities of a country in which English is not an official language appropriate to the place where the evidence is to be taken, and unless the court orders otherwise, a translation of the documents referred to in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) into an official language of that country appropriate to that place, and
must file:
a copy of each of the documents referred to in paragraph (a), and
an undertaking by the party obtaining the order, or his or her solicitor, to pay all expenses incurred by the court, or by any person at the request of the court, in respect of the letter of request.

A translation filed under subrule (1)(a) must be certified by the person making it to be a correct translation, and the certificate must state the person’s full name and address and the office or qualification by reason of which the person so certifies.

As indicated in [24.2.10] and [24.3.40] , the practice of issuing letters of request to the courts of foreign jurisdictions grew as a means of overcoming both the inability to compel a reluctant witness to attend an examination, and the consequences of foreign legislation regulating the taking of evidence on oath. Although such letters of request imposed no obligation on the foreign courts, considerations of comity led to acceptance of the procedure. By the mid-nineteenth century the practice had been facilitated by legislation, such as the Foreign Tribunals Evidence Act 1856 (UK) . It is now the subject of the 18 March 1970 Hague Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters, and the legislation referred to in [24.1.5] .

level.toc-caption: [24.5.10] The Hague Convention and related legislation

heading.title: The Hague Convention and related legislation

p.text: The form of letters of request is governed by Article 3 of the 18 March 1970 Hague Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters — Australian Treaty Series 1992, No 37. (Australia acceded to that convention on 23 October 1992. Australia’s accession is subject to various declarations, including a refusal, pursuant to Article 23 of the Convention, to execute letters of request seeking discovery of documents). The Convention came into force for Australia on 22 December 1992.

Article 3 of the Hague Convention requires a letter of request to specify various matters, including the nature of, and the parties to, the proceedings, the evidence to be obtained and the persons to be examined. A letter of request may ask either for an oral examination or may be accompanied by specific interrogatories that the examiner is to put to the witness (the usual procedure in many foreign courts is that the court alone puts the questions). Where the evidence is to be obtained by means of written questions they may be required to be provided in advance to the other party so that appropriate “cross-examination” matters can be raised. Likewise the cross-examination questions should be disclosed to the requesting party so that “re-examination” questions can be formulated. Irrespective of the contemplated procedure for the proposed examination, the letter of request should include a comprehensive summary of the proceedings and explain with sufficient particularity the nature of the evidence that is required. A model for letters of request recommended for use in applying the convention appears in the Practical Handbook on the operation of the Hague Convention of 18 March 1970 on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil Matters; Maarten Kluwer's Internationale Uitgeversonderneming 1984; The Hague Conventions on the Service of Process, the Taking of Evidence and Legalisation, McClean, Commonwealth Secretariat, London, 1979. Alternatively, many of the reported cases, such as Pickles v Gratzon (2002) 55 NSWLR 533 at 538–9; [2002] NSWSC 688; BC200204345 outline the appropriate contents of a letter of request.
Legislation cited in [24.5.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 33(3), s 33(6).

The power to order, or issue a letter of request for, the examination of a witness does not include an unrestricted power to require the production of documents: see s 33(6) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995; Elna Australia Pty Ltd v International Computers (Aust) Pty Ltd (1987) 14 FCR 461 at 466; 74 ALR 232 ; Novotny v Todd [2002] WASCA 79; BC200201602 (letters of request proposed to be issued to the “proper officer” of a corporation). An order may be made for the production of documents ancillary to the evidentiary examination of a witness: see Panayiotou v Sony Music [1994] Ch 142; [1994] 1 All ER 755 ; Novotny v Todd , above, at [51]–[52]; s 33(3) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. That incidental power permits a limited order for production against either a proposed witness or another person: Penn-Texas Corp v Murat Anstalt [1964] 1 QB 40 at 52–63; [1963] 1 All ER 258; but it does not authorise an order for “discovery”: Panthalu v Ramnord Research Laboratories Ltd [1966] 2 QB 173 at 189. In this context, “discovery” includes the production of documents for the purpose of “ascertaining whether they may be useful rather than... adducing them in evidence as proof of some fact”: Novotny v Todd , above, at [55]; Radio Corp of America v Rauland Corp [1956] 1 QB 618 at 631, 635, 644, 648; [1956] 1 All ER 549; Burchard v Macfarlane [1891] 2 QB 241 at 244. Orders for production, pursuant to letters of request, are considered in [SCR 58.2.2] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.6] r 24.6 Evidence otherwise than on oath (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2B; DCR Part 25, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Evidence otherwise than on oath (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2B; DCR Part 25, rule 7)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise:
a person may be examined outside Australia, otherwise than on oath, under an order under rule 24.3(1)(c) , and

evidence of a person may be taken outside Australia, otherwise than on oath, under an order under section 6(1)(c) or 20(1)(c) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995, or under an order of the same kind made under section 9 or 23 of that Act,
if the person is examined or the evidence is taken in accordance with the procedure of the country concerned.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.7] r 24.7 Documents for examiner (cf SCR Part 27, rule 3; DCR Part 25, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Documents for examiner (cf SCR Part 27, rule 3; DCR Part 25, rule 8)

p.text: The party obtaining an order for examination before an examiner must furnish the examiner with copies of such of the documents in the proceedings as are necessary to inform the examiner of the issues to which the examination is to relate.

If the documents in the proceedings are not sufficient to inform the examiner of the issues to which the examination is to relate, the court may, in the order for examination or in a later order, state the issues to which the examination is to relate.
This rule does not apply if the examiner is a judicial officer of the court by which the order for examination was made.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.8] r 24.8 Appointment for examination (cf SCR Part 27, rule 4; DCR Part 25, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Appointment for examination (cf SCR Part 27, rule 4; DCR Part 25, rule 9)

p.text: The examiner is to appoint a place (and, subject to the order for examination, a time) for the examination.
The time appointed by the examiner must be as soon as practicable after the making of the order, having regard to all the circumstances (including the convenience of the person to be examined).

The examiner must give notice of an appointment under this rule to the party obtaining the order and, not less than 3 days before the time appointed, that party must give notice of the appointment to each other party.

level.toc-caption: [24.8.5] The power to compel a witness' attendance

p.text: Legislation cited in [24.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 33.

heading.title: The power to compel a witness' attendance

p.text: An order for examination under the provisions of the rules is addressed to the examiner and confers authority to conduct the examination. It does not compel the attendance of the proposed witness: Stuart v Balkis Co (1884) 50 LT 479. If a power of compulsion is required then, if the examination takes place in Australia, the witness must be served with a subpoena under Part 33 of the rules. However, if a witness attends the examination without having been served with a subpoena he or she will be taken to have waived the requirement and is then compellable: Cutler v Wright [1890] WN 28. If the examination takes place overseas then the existence of any power to compel attendance will depend upon local law.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.9] r 24.9 Conduct of examination (cf SCR Part 27, rule 5; DCR Part 25, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Conduct of examination (cf SCR Part 27, rule 5; DCR Part 25, rule 10)

p.text: The examiner must permit the parties to attend the examination, together with their barristers and solicitors.
Subject to this Part, the proceedings before the examiner are to be in accordance with the procedure of the court.
Unless the court orders otherwise:
a person who is examined before an examiner may be cross-examined and re-examined, and
the examination, cross-examination and re-examination of such a person are to be conducted in the same way as at a trial.
The examiner may put any question to a person being examined:
as to the meaning of any answer made by that person, or
as to any matter arising in the course of the examination.
The examiner may adjourn the examination from time to time or from place to place.
Legislation cited in [24.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence on Commission Act 1995 21, s 33(1), Sections 7.
(CTH) Foreign Evidence Act 1994 s 8.

Sections 7 and 21 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 and s 8 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 (Cth) permit the court to give directions relating to the procedure to be followed in any examination ordered for the purpose of proceedings in the court. Subject to any such direction, the court’s ordinary trial procedures and forum evidentiary law govern the examination. Where the court orders, pursuant to letters of request, an examination for foreign proceedings, s 33(1) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 grants power to make “such provision... as appears appropriate” to give effect to the request — subject to the limitation that the required conduct must be permissible for the purpose of taking evidence in proceedings in the court: see [SCR 58.2.1] . (Contrast England v Smith [2001] 1 Ch 419; [2000] 2 WLR 1141 where the legislation permitted application of the law of the requesting jurisdiction). Subject to these general discretionary principles, the examiner must allow the parties and their legal representatives to be present at the examination. The implication from this express requirement is that the examination is regarded as otherwise being held in private: Re Western of Canada Oil, Lands & Works Co (1877) 6 Ch D 109; Eubanks v Cannar [2003] NSWSC 1267; BC200308541 . However a person to be examined has a right to retain legal advice and representation in connection with the examination: see Pickles v Gratzon (2002) 55 NSWLR 533 at 555; [2002] NSWSC 688; BC200204345 ; Application of Cannar; Re Eubanks [2003] NSWSC 802 at [15]; BC200305881 ; Re Norway's Application [1987] 1 QB 433 at 498–9 per Ralph Gibson LJ citing Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547 at 562–3; [1978] 1 All ER 434 . Subject to the assertion of any such rights (and subject to any contrary direction of the court), the examiner has a discretion to permit any other persons to be present: Wright v Wilkin (1858) 6 WR 643. The stipulation that the examination is to be conducted in like manner to a trial means that the examiner must determine the competence of the witness to be examined: White v Hoddle (1880) 6 VLR (E) 82; may utilise the services of an interpreter: Marquess of Bute v James (1886) 33 Ch D 157; may permit the parties to conduct the questioning at the examination: Vimbos v Meadowcroft (1901) 46 Sol Jo 2; can allow a witness to be treated as hostile: Ohlsen v Terrero (1874) LR 10 Ch 127; and determine that the rules in relation to notices to produce and the issue of subpoenas may apply (where the examination occurs within the jurisdiction of the court's process). If more than one witness is to be examined there is force in the consideration that the order in which they should be examined is a matter for the party calling the witness, as would be the ordinary position at a trial: Briscoe v Briscoe [1968] P 501 . However, the authorities suggest that the examiner does have some discretion as to the order in which the examinations take place: Stuart v Balkis Co (1884) 50 LT 479; Re Dore Gallery (1890) 62 LT 758.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.10] r 24.10 Examination of additional persons (cf SCR Part 27, rule 6; DCR Part 25, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Examination of additional persons (cf SCR Part 27, rule 6; DCR Part 25, rule 11)

p.text: On the application of a party to the proceedings, an examiner who is a judicial officer of the court may examine any person not named or provided for in the order for examination.

With the written consent of each party to the proceedings, an examiner who is not a judicial officer of the court may examine any person not named or provided for in the order for examination and, if he or she does so, must annex those consents to the transcript of that person’s evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.11] r 24.11 Objection (cf SCR Part 27, rule 7; DCR Part 25, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Objection (cf SCR Part 27, rule 7; DCR Part 25, rule 12)

p.text: If a party objects to a question put to a person being examined, or a person being examined objects to answering such a question or to producing any document or thing:
the examiner must state to the parties his or her opinion, but must not decide, on the validity of the objection, and

the question, the ground for the objection, the examiner’s opinion on the objection and the answer (if any) of the person being examined must be set out in the transcript of that person’s evidence or in a statement attached to the transcript, and
the court may, on motion by any party, decide the validity of the objection, and
if the court decides against the objector, the court may order the objector to pay the costs occasioned by the objection.
This rule does not apply if the examiner is a judicial officer of the court.

The court may reject evidence irregularly adduced before the examiner: Hutchinson v Bernard (1836) 2 Macl & Rob 1; 174 ER 194; Graham v Graham (1872) 3 VR (E) 139; 3 AJR 55; Hatt v Hatt (1877) 3 VLR (E) 227; Baynes v Osborne (1873) 4 QSCR 1 at 12–14. However, a party’s failure to object at the examination may be relied on to exclude reconsideration of its admissibility at the trial of the principal proceedings: Robinson v Davies (1879) 5 QBD 26 at 27–28 per Lush J, Manisty agreeing. Some difficulty arises where it is unclear whether evidence received on commission was in fact objected to and the objection overruled: eg Graham v Graham (1872) 3 VR (E) 139 at 141; 3 AJR 55 at 56 per Molesworth J. However, it has been observed that whatever weight a judge might give to the circumstances that no objection had been taken before a commissioner, any practice, whereby such objections are overruled without argument must be taken with limitations. There may be reasons which explain the lack of objection, and some problems may result from making rulings on admissibility in advance of the trial: Baynes v Osborne (1873) 4 QSCR 1 at 12–15 per Cockle CJ; see also R v His Honour Judge Noud, Ex parte Macnamara [1991] 2 Qd R 86 at 92 per McPherson J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.12] r 24.12 Recording of evidence generally (cf SCR Part 27, rule 8; DCR Part 25, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Recording of evidence generally (cf SCR Part 27, rule 8; DCR Part 25, rule 13)

p.text: The evidence taken at an examination must be recorded in writing (whether longhand or shorthand) or by some other method (whether mechanical, electronic or otherwise) that is capable of making a permanent record of the evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.13] r 24.13 Audio-visual recording of evidence (cf SCR Part 27, rule 8A; DCR Part 25, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Audio-visual recording of evidence (cf SCR Part 27, rule 8A; DCR Part 25, rule 14)

p.text: The court or the examiner may give directions for the making of an audio-visual recording of the proceedings on an examination.

In Hyslop v Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd (No 2) [1987] VR 309 an order for videotaping was made without the authority of a specific rule such as r 24.13. In J Barber and Sons v Lloyds Underwriters [1987] 1 QB 103 an order was made under the Evidence (Proceedings in Other Jurisdictions) Act 1975 (UK) requiring the examination of the witnesses to be recorded on video tape. A similar order was made in B v Dentists Disciplinary Tribunal [1994] 1 NZLR 95 (which contains detailed directions about the procedure to be followed).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.14] r 24.14 Authentication and filing (cf SCR Part 27, rule 9; DCR Part 25, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Authentication and filing (cf SCR Part 27, rule 9; DCR Part 25, rule 15)

p.text: A transcript of the evidence recorded in relation to an examination must be prepared and the person who prepares the transcript must certify that it is a correct transcript of the evidence so recorded.
The examiner must sign the transcript of the evidence and any document that constitutes a recording under rule 24.13.

The examiner must certify on the transcript, or on a separate document annexed to the transcript, as to the time occupied in the examination and as to the fees received by the examiner in respect of the examination.
The examiner must send the transcript of the evidence, and any document that constitutes a recording under rule 24.13, to the registrar and the registrar must file them in the proceedings.
Unless the court orders otherwise, the examiner must send the exhibits to the registrar, and the registrar must deal with the exhibits in such manner as the court may direct.
Subrules (1), (3) and (4) do not apply if the examiner is a judicial officer of the court.
Legislation cited in [24.14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 75.
(CTH) Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 1989 s 19.

The failure of the examiner to sign the record of the examination has been held to be an irregularity only and does not prevent the subsequent use of the evidence: Stephens v Wanklin (1854) 19 Beav 585; Felthouse v Bailey (1866) 14 WR 827 (examiner died before signing). In other contexts objections to tender of a transcript of evidence on the sole ground that the transcripts are not signed by the examinees or authenticated in any other prescribed manner, may be overruled where the hearing is interlocutory and hearsay evidence is admissible under s 75 of the Evidence Act 1995. A person present at an examination may exhibit the transcript to an affidavit and depose that a document contains a true transcription of the statement made by an examinee (the transcript related to an examination under s 19 of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 Cth): Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Elm Financial Services Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 306; BC200402126 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.15] r 24.15 Special report (cf SCR Part 27, rule 10; DCR Part 25, rule 16)

leg:heading.title: Special report (cf SCR Part 27, rule 10; DCR Part 25, rule 16)

p.text: The examiner may furnish to the court a special report with regard to any examination conducted by the examiner and with regard to the absence of any person from, or the conduct of any person at, the examination.
The court may direct such proceedings to be taken, or make such order, on the report as the court thinks fit.

This provision permits the examiner to record facts that occurred at the examination and which may be relevant to the assessment of the evidence. For example, the special report may record the witness' movement or demeanour at a particular time or the witness' activity in reading a document or pausing before answering a question. However the special report does not permit the examiner to express an opinion about the credibility of the witness: Re Wipperman; Wisler v Wipperman [1955] P 59 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.16] r 24.16 Default of witness (cf SCR Part 27, rule 11; DCR Part 25, rule 17)

leg:heading.title: Default of witness (cf SCR Part 27, rule 11; DCR Part 25, rule 17)

p.text: If a person, required by subpoena to attend before an examiner who is not a judicial officer of the court:
refuses to be sworn for the purposes of the examination, or
refuses to answer any lawful question, or
refuses to produce any document or thing,
the examiner must, at the request of any party, give to that party a certificate, signed by the examiner, of the refusal.
On the certificate being filed, and on motion by any party, the court:
may order the person to be sworn, or to answer the question or to produce the document or thing, as the case may be, and
may order the person to pay any costs occasioned by the refusal.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.17] r 24.17 Order for payment of expenses (cf SCR Part 27, rule 12; DCR Part 25, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Order for payment of expenses (cf SCR Part 27, rule 12; DCR Part 25, rule 18)

p.text: If a party fails to comply with an undertaking referred to in rule 24.5(1)(b)(ii) within 7 days after service on the party of notice of the amount of the expenses concerned, the court:
may order the party to pay the amount of the expenses to the registrar by a specified date, and
if the party fails to comply with that order by the specified date, may give such judgment, or make such order, as it thinks fit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.18] r 24.18 Perpetuation of testimony (cf SCR Part 27, rule 13; DCR Part 25, rule 19)

leg:heading.title: Perpetuation of testimony (cf SCR Part 27, rule 13; DCR Part 25, rule 19)

p.text: Witnesses may not be examined to perpetuate testimony unless proceedings to perpetuate that testimony have been commenced.

Any person may commence proceedings to perpetuate testimony that may be material for establishing any right or claim to any relief, which right or claim cannot be established before the happening of a future event.
If proceedings to perpetuate testimony touch any matter or thing in which the Crown may have an interest, the Attorney General may be made a defendant.

If, under subrule (3), the Attorney General is made a defendant to proceedings to perpetuate testimony, evidence taken in those proceedings is not inadmissible in other proceedings just because the Crown was not a party to the proceedings to perpetuate testimony.
Subrule (2) does not affect the right of any person to commence proceedings to perpetuate testimony in cases to which that subrule does not apply.

Proceedings to perpetuate testimony are now rare, their purpose is stated in r 24.18(2): see also Kelly v Kelly [1917] 1 IR 51; Campbell v Earl of Dalhousie (1869) LR 1 Sc & Div 462; Moggridge v Hall (1879) 13 Ch D 380 and see also Story's Equity Jurisprudence, 14th ed, 1918, pp 1505–1512. The evidence in such proceedings is usually taken before an examiner: Marquess of Bute v James (1886) 33 Ch D 157 .

An order for the publication of the record taken in an action for the perpetuation of testimony must be made before they can be used in subsequent proceedings: Vane v Vane (1876) 45 LJ Ch 589; Anzon v Tooth [1917] WN (NSW) 234. Such an order will not be made unless the witnesses are dead or unable by reason of illness, incapacity or distance to attend the hearing: Beresford v A-G [1918] P 33 ; Ranken v Pearce (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 410 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.19] r 24.19 Operation of directions under Evidence on Commission Act 1995 (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2A; DCR Part 25, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Operation of directions under Evidence on Commission Act 1995 (cf SCR Part 27, rule 2A; DCR Part 25, rule 6)

p.text: To the extent to which they deal with matters arising under the Evidence on Commission Act 1995, the provisions of this Part are subject to any directions given by a superior court under section 7 or 21 of that Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 24.20] r 24.20 Witness expenses (cf DCR Part 25, rule 21)

leg:heading.title: Witness expenses (cf DCR Part 25, rule 21)

p.text: A witness attending before an examiner to be examined, or to produce a document, is entitled to payment of the same amount for conduct money expenses and loss of time as he or she would have been entitled to on attending to give evidence, or to produce a document, at the trial of the proceedings before the court.
Legislation cited in [24.20.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.11.
This rule provides for the same entitlement for expenses for persons examined other than at trial as persons who are subpoenaed to give evidence. See notes to r 33.11 .
